messages.subject: "Everything Bad is Good for You"
messages.msgSnippet: Funny you should ask.  I finished the book yesterday.  I loved it! Hmmm..maybe not loved , but I really like it
messages.messageBody:
<<Has anyone else read this article or book?>>



Funny you should ask. I finished the book yesterday. I loved it!
Hmmm..maybe not "loved", but I really like it a lot! The subtitle is "How
Today's Popular Culture is Actually Making Us Smarter." I found it while
browsing the bookstore a few days ago. I decided to go ahead and buy it,
hoping that it might be a good loaner book - i.e. to the moms of all my
son's friends who have to earn privileges to play games (who LOVE to come to
our house, where they can play Nintendo & X-box all they want LOL).



I plan to check out his other books. He does discuss the value of playing
video games, but also talks about a lot more - how our culture is not
"dumbing down" like many articles claim. He talks about how everything is
becoming increasingly complex - tv shows, movies, video games (PacMan vs.
Simcity) and so forth. He spends some time analyzing popular tv shows
(Sopranos, 24) and discusses the complex social relationships and story
lines that a viewer has to keep track of that older shows didn't have. He
points out that many popular shows (The Simpsons) & movies (Harry Potter,
Finding Nemo) are now intergenerational - parents & kids can both enjoy the
same show together, because of the layered meanings and references hidden
inside many shows (which shows have to have now, because of technological
advances like recording - so we can watch the same show multiple times, so
it better be interesting or we'll be bored and not buy it on DVD). He talks
about how tv shows are more participatory - yes, even "passively" watching
tv - and exercise our emotional intelligence ("What would I have done if I
had been on that episode of Survivor?").



He uses economics, technology and neurobiology to help explain his theories
in part two. He even discusses IQ scores.

He claims that the violence in video games that critics complain about is a
non-issue. The content of the game, including the violence, is only
incidental to the problem solving required to complete the game. He talks
about how some argue that book reading is in decline, but says those same
folks fail to point out that everything else is also in decline. We have so
many more options today and so spread our time out among many different
activities, of which book reading is just one. He also talks about how we
are doing more of our reading & writing online (duh!).



I found it interesting that near the end, he backtracks a bit as if he's
afraid he's going to be criticized and makes a disclaimer. Ok, here it
is.page 193 (the "book" ends at page 199 although "Notes" continue to
pages 234): "I realize that, in writing this book, I have set myself up to
be misrepresented as the guy who argues that kids should be allowed to play
Doom all day, and never open a novel. So let me be clear for the parents
who are reading this. Yes, the trends are toward more media complexity;
yes, games and television shows and films have cognitive rewards that we
should better understand and value...Where our media diets are concerned for
all of us ---young, old, or somewhere in the middle-the commonsense rule
still applies: moderation in everything."



But then he states his case again :-) -

"But neither should we deny ourselves the occasional obsession. These are
deep, rich worlds being created on our screens; you can't truly experience
them-you can't probe their physics and telescope your way through their
multiple objectives-without becoming a little obsessed in the process. Out
of obsession comes expertise, a confidence in your own powers of analysis -
a sense that if you stick with the system long enough, you'll truly figure
out how it works."



Heather M

- mom to Quentin (age 9, future pokemon master <g> & excellent Halo
player) & Sierra (age 6)

- in Tucson AZ

messages.msgSnippet: I am a lurker too but have a similar experience. We pulled my eleven year old son out of public school in February after he was having a demoralizing time in a
messages.messageBody:
I am a lurker too but have a similar experience. We pulled my eleven year old son out of public school in February after he was having a demoralizing time in a very rigid middle school. (Middle school starts in fifth grade in our district).

My husband who is home more than I is more sold on unschooling and I have my ups and downs about it. Right now I am feeling more optimistic as I see my son grow more vibrant and confident and as our relationship, which I didn't know needed improvement, has deepened.

Yet since we have settled into unschooling he does spend most of his time playing computer and video games, doing computer graphics and some television. He was in the gifted program and has acquired basic school skills and that is some consolation although I get scared when I imagine that he will never advance beyond what he has now. Yet in my more open-minded moods, I see that in addition to these games, he is participating on online forums in which he writes letters and stories and creates animation.

I also read a very encouraging article in the May 16 New Yorker called "Brain Candy" which reviewed a book called "Everything Bad is Good for You" by Steven Johnson. Johnson seems to be arguing that video games are good for cognitive development encourage fluid problem solving, (as opposed to crystallized knowledge. Here's a quote from the review: "Johnson describes video games as play for an adolescent: an unstructured environment that requires the child actively to intervene to look for the hidden logic, to find order and meaning in chaos." He even discusses the comparative lack of value of homework which he says has no proven benefits. Johnson attributes society's enamorment of homework with our lack of faith in the value of things children would be doing on their own.

This certainly spoke to me as a fledgling unschooling parents. Has anyone else read this article or book?
Andrea
